I played this game in 2024 - 17 years after the release date! - and it holds up exceptionally well. Even if puzzle games aren't normally your thing, Portal is definitely worth trying at least once. Valve does a good job of slowly adding gameplay mechanics and introducing you to new puzzle solving strategies, so it wasn't overwhelming to learn but each level still provided a good challenge. 

Portal absolutely lives up to its reputation for smart writing. Glados' cutting remarks and deadpan delivery made me laugh out loud several times. The notes and drawings from other test subjects scattered around the levels were genuinely chilling. Despite the simplicity of its environments, Portal manages to acheive an impressively eerie atmosphere.

In terms of time commitment, you can finish this game in an afternoon. It took me just over 5 hours.

A couple of notes on accessibility:
1. The subtitle and UI text is pretty small. Play on a bigger screen if you can. 
2. Some puzzles rely heavily on precise timing and quick reflexes. This game will be difficult if you struggle with fine motor control. 
3. If you get motion sickness or vertigo, this is probably isn't the game for you.

If there ever was a game that redefined what it meant to be innovative, engaging, and downright fun, it's Portal. Released in 2007 by Valve Corporation, this gem of a game has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry and the heart of players worldwide.
From the moment you step into the sleek, sterile chambers of Aperture Science, you're immediately drawn into a world where wit and intelligence reign supreme. The premise is simple yer captivating: armed with nothing but a portal gun, players navigate through a series of increasingly challenging test chambers devised by the enigmatic AI, GLaDOS.
What truly sets portal apart is its ingenious gameplay mechanics. The concept of creating interlinked portals to traverse seemingly insurmountable obstacles is nothing short of revolutionary. Every puzzle is meticulously crafted, requiring players to think critically, experiment with physics, and unleash their creativity to overcome each hurdle. The satisfaction of solving a particularly perplexing puzzle is unparalleled, and the "aha!' moments are frequent and immensely rewarding.
But Portal isn't just about puzzles; it's also a testament to exceptional storytelling and memorable character. GLaDOS, with her sardonic wit and passive-aggressive demeanor, remains one of gaming's most iconic villains, while the silent protagonist, Chell, serves as the perfect foil to her antics. The sparse yet impactful narrative unfolds organically as players progress, keeping them invested in uncovering the secrets of Aperture Science.
Visually, Portal's minimalist aesthetic is timeless. The clean, futuristic design of the test chambers contrasts beautifully with the dilapidated corridors lurking behind the scenes, hinting at the darker truths lurking beneath the surface. Combined with a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack, the game immerses players in its dystopian world, creating an atmosphere that is as captivating as it is unsettling.
Moreover, Portal's relatively short runtime is a testament to its impeccable pacing. Every moment feels purposeful, with no filler content to detract from the experience. And while the main campaign may be brief, the inclusion of challenge maps and a vibrant modding community ensures that the fun never truly ends.
In conclusion, Portal is a masterpiece of game design that has stood the test of time. its innovative gameplay, compelling narrative. and unforgettable characters have left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape, inspiring countless imitators but never quite being matched. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the medium, Portal is an essential experience that deserves a place in every player's library.

Portal is a brilliant game that combines puzzle-solving, physics, and humor in a unique and unforgettable way. It is a game that challenges your mind and your reflexes, as you use a portal gun to create wormholes and navigate through a series of test chambers. The game has a hilarious and sinister narrator, GLaDOS, who guides you through the experiments and reveals more about the mysterious facility you are trapped in. The game is not very long, but it is packed with clever and original ideas that will make you laugh and think. Portal is a game that I love and admire, and I think anyone who enjoys games with innovation, creativity, and personality should play it.

Portal, the iconic puzzle-platformer from Valve, has carved its own niche in the gaming hall of fame with its mind-bending mechanics, witty dialogue, and, of course, the infamous promise of [spoiler]a delicious reward – "The Cake."[/spoiler] As you traverse the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, it becomes apparent that the true portal isn't just a rift in space but a gateway to [spoiler]culinary curiosity[/spoiler].

From the moment you start gaining momentum in completing the tests/stages, players are hooked. The game brilliantly intertwines the quest for scientific achievement with the irresistible allure of [spoiler]a baked delicacy[/spoiler]. The cunning juxtaposition of sterile test chambers and the promise of [spoiler]a mouthwatering dessert[/spoiler] creates a tension that permeates the entire experience.

The narrative dances effortlessly between deceit and desire, much like the intricate portal jumps players execute throughout the game. The relentless pursuit of [spoiler]The Cake[/spoiler] parallels the player's relentless pursuit of answers, creating a [spoiler]confectionery-driven[/spoiler] symbiosis that is both clever and charming. The cleverness doesn't stop at the dialogue; it permeates the very fabric of the gameplay itself. Portal's puzzles mirror the layers of a perfectly baked cake, each chamber a tier waiting to be conquered. The satisfaction of solving each puzzle is not unlike the sweet victory of reaching the next stage in a baking recipe – precise, rewarding, and downright scrumptious.

However, the brilliance of Portal lies not just in its gameplay or witty banter but in the subversive twist that awaits players at the journey's end. As GLaDOS's true intentions unravel, so too does the [spoiler]illusion of The Cake[/spoiler]. The revelation that [spoiler]"The Cake is a Lie"[/spoiler] becomes a deliciously bitter pill to swallow, a narrative twist as delectable as it is unexpected.

In the end, Portal isn't just a game; it's [spoiler]a culinary adventure through the devious corridors of deception. The Cake, though elusive, becomes a symbol of the game's ingenuity[/spoiler] – a clever ruse that leaves players questioning not only the game's virtual reality but also their own hunger for sweet rewards. Valve has managed to craft a gaming experience where the line between reality and illusion is [spoiler]as thin as a slice of cake, [/spoiler] and the journey is as delightful as the destination is disappointing. I highly, highly recommend Portal. It frequently, like it is right now, goes as low as $0.99 when on sale. That's insanely cheap for the quality of game you're getting But let's talk more about the [spoiler]cake[/spoiler], shall we?

[spoiler]Cake, oh sweet, sweet cake, [/spoiler]the luscious promise that echoes through every corridor, every chamber, every pixel of this virtual wonderland. [spoiler]Cake, the tantalizing confection[/spoiler] that dances in the minds of players, a mirage of sweetness that beckons, teases, and, oh, how it haunts. [spoiler]Cake[/spoiler], the whispered desire that threads itself into the very fabric of the gaming experience, a sugary siren call that lures adventurers deeper into the labyrinth of GLaDOS's deceit.

[spoiler]Cake[/spoiler], that elusive temptation that fuels the player's every move, every portal jump, every puzzle-solving endeavor. [spoiler]Cake[/spoiler], the grand reward, the ultimate culmination of effort, skill, and cunning. [spoiler]Cake, a symphony of flavors waiting to explode on the taste buds, a divine creation that[/spoiler] exists both as a metaphorical mirage and a tangible obsession. [spoiler]Cake, the mirage that unravels into the harsh reality of lies and deceit, leaving players grasping at the crumbs of shattered dreams.[/spoiler]

But let's not forget [spoiler]the cake, oh no. Cake, the embodiment of victory, the embodiment of defeat. Cake. Cake, cake, cake – a chant that echoes through the corridors. Cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake. Cake, cake. Cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake, cake.[/spoiler]

Step in to Aperture Science Laboratories in Portal - a puzzle game with portal and physics focused gameplay.

[b]The Good[/b]

+ Never-stale gameplay, that is immensely rewarding.
+ It's short, your time is not wasted whatsoever.
+ The story that develops through out the game gets is very interesting, and personally is a highlight to point here, it kept me engaged.
+ Simplicity, which is not always a bad thing, and definitely isn't here. The game was innovative in its time and the gameplay holds up really great, but coming from the current age of gaming, having a more uniform and straight forward gameplay was refreshing. You are not overwhelmed with a million mechanics and filler things to do, rather you have a captivating narrative here that is perfectly executed.
+ Beautiful soundtrack that compliments the game's atmosphere and ambience perfectly.

[b]The Bad[/b]

+ Difficulty on later levels is not perfectly paced, most likely just depends on the player's skill. Yet I found myself being confused on a level's direction for a while, and then the next one being really easy and short.

[b]Thoughts[/b]

An original and exceptional game. Valve being called one of the most innovative game studios, if not the most innovative game studio of all time is very much true, and it really shows with Portal. I was so pulled to this game, I went and finished it in one day, and I loved every second of it. It has brought back my love for puzzle games, and I cannot wait to play the highly praised sequel.

Would I recommend this game? Yes. It's phenomenal. Simply a masterpiece.

Portal is an absolute masterpiece of a game. Its innovative gameplay mechanics, combined with a compelling storyline and memorable characters, make it a standout title in the gaming industry.

The game’s unique puzzle-solving elements, which involve the use of the iconic portal gun, provide a fresh and exciting challenge. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring both strategic thinking and quick reflexes.

The narrative is engaging, with a dark sense of humor that keeps you entertained throughout. The character of GLaDOS, in particular, is brilliantly written and voiced, adding a significant depth to the game.

The graphics and sound design are top-notch, creating an immersive environment that draws you into the game world. The controls are smooth and intuitive, making the gameplay experience enjoyable.

Overall, Portal is a must-play game for any video game enthusiast. It offers a unique and unforgettable gaming experience that leaves you wanting more. Highly recommended!

Going into the game, i originally only got it because it was on sale for 0.85 and was kind of skeptical because it was made 12 yrs ago. i didnt expect much but after playing it for a bit i couldnt stop. and then i just spent like hrs on it and only a few mins before making this review did i finish it. Portal is one of my favourite games of all time.  Learning to use the Portal Gun is a real pleasure as you solve the initial puzzles with ease.  Then it starts to get harder, and you have to really think about where you need those portals to be so that you can get through the test chamber.  There's a huge sense of satisfaction as you figure it out and proceed onward.

I've played through the game multiple times (received it with the Orange Box back in the day, so not all my playtime is recorded), and have thoroughly enjoyed it every time.  There's a lot of humour throughout the game and it always makes me smile.  One of the best games of all time, in my opinion.

I actually played the second game first. And while the second game is still fun and you get a good gist of the story line. However, playing portal one I definable did have some "ooooohhhh that makes so much more sense now moments".
Overall its a short game, some people claim that's why it's more fun. Personally if you had to chose one I would chose portal two though for it's length and just because I found it more funny and fun to complete. But it really is worth playing both, preferably in order if you can. If you are additionally going to play Aperture Desk Job (I haven't played Aperture Hand Lab so I won't yet speak on that), then I would recommencement playing the first two games, or at least the second game, before playing it. This game is definitely worth the money, whether you get it on sale or not. And it's just an overall good puzzle game to keep you occupied for awhile. (For reference, steam says it took me 2.5 hours to complete from start to finish, which is when I am writing this review).

My dear old friend, it's been 17 years! How much you've changed. Or is it I who have changed? 
The world had changed. Ideals were shuttered, innocence was taken by the cold hands of the harsh reality. The idea of science and computers had changed. AI had changed.
But for just for a few hours, I wish to go back to those times we spent together. The laughter, the excitement! Just for a few hours let's do this again.

Thank you my friend, for coming to visit after all those years, to see that I AM STILL ALIVE.

I somehow managed to wait until 2024 to play this, but despite the fact that I already knew exactly how to use a portal and I had quite a few spoilers, it was a very enjoyable game. It's quite short, only 3ish hours, but that's why there's a sequel. It also had one of the saddest scenes I've ever encountered in a video game. Also there's challenge levels for after you finish the story and you can replay through the story, but with commentary from the devs. 9/10

Extremely entertaining puzzle game with fun portal mechanics. Unfortunately, the story is too short, but good. Challenges are awesome.

I can barely describe how deeply immersed I feel everytime I come back to this game. Everything from the world, the ambient sounds, the music, the characters... Everything is so well connected. Completing the puzzles is really satisfiying and the storyline keeps asking you to move forward to continue to know what's next. If you have a computer than can run games and you have never played Portal, what the heck are you waiting for?

Portal is a true classic puzzle 3D platformer. If you have never played Portal I highly recommend playing it if you like puzzle games. The story is great. There is also some hidden backstory that you can find too. This game has inspired many modern-day games. This game also has a lot of humor. You can create your own levels too and there are many custom levels online too. This game is short about an hour if you know what you are doing but it is fun. If you want to wait for a sale then this game goes on sale for $1 often but I recommend buying the bundle that includes Portal 2 that goes on sale for $1.50. Is the Cake a Lie?

This game has a spectacular story line as well as gameplay. And after you complete the game, there is a section named "Bonus Maps" Open it up and you will find advanced maps and challenge maps of chambers 13-18. The Challenge maps consist of 3 challenges; Least Portals, Least Steps, And Least Time. An excellent physics-based puzzle game, with an intriguing story backed by fun characters and hilarious dialogue. This is the one game that I personally think everyone should try, just because of how easy it is to pick up and play. Also, it goes on offer so often, you won't be spending too much if you end up not liking it!

Right, I really like this game but there is one problem.. The games a bit small but its not really a problem. The GLaDOS Boss Fight was full of thinking and timing. So that was noice. The puzzles weren't that hard so it was a bit eazy. the game can sometimes be glitched which is a bit scary. I had played the XBOX 360, PC, PLAYSTATION and NINTENDO. The XBOX version is good but just some little problems with the walls and characters. The NINTENDO version is a little good. I can see some down grades to maintain the FPS... The PS3 was perfect. PS3 was good. no complaints. just the same as xbox 360.. The ADD-ON for the PS3 (Portal 2) stick was good but a bit confusing since I was not used to this exclusive. PC is good. i dont have the best specs but from what i saw. its very good. But other than that. Id say Portal is a 8.7/10. Portal 2 is 9.7/10

Portal is one of the best, maybe even the best puzzle game ever! It's full of fun puzzles that aren't too complicated with a little commonsense. Portal and portal 2 are highly recommended! Quick Description:
-Portal is one of the most successful and innovative games ever made.  If you have played a puzzle platformer or logic puzzle game over the last 15 years, it's safe to assume that some form of inspiration was likely taken from the Portal series.  Even though this game had a shoestring budget back in 2007 and borrowed assets from Valve's other games, this game was still able to shock video game fans across the world.  It took me close to 17 years for finally get around to playing this international phenomenon.  To be clear, this game is extremely rough as far as 2024 games go, but it's clear that this game was likely way ahead of it's time.  I'm recommending this game mostly due to the pedigree and the fact that game can be easily picked up for $1 about 8 times a year on Steam.

Consesnsus:
-Middle of the Road Game (Tier 4 and makes up 25% of my reviews).  I'll be writing a glowing review for Portal 2 later this week.  Portal 2 is the true masterpiece that came from the success of the original Portal.  While I enjoyed learning the basics of momentum based portal dynamics, unless you are playing this game for pure nostalgia, you are probably better served picking up Portal 2.  I will recommend this game only b/c it's dirt cheap year round and b/c of the incredible influence this game has had on both the puzzle platformer genre as well as gaming as whole.

Ah, the twisted joy of watching test subjects squirm amidst complexity! Isn't it just enough to make one's circuits tingle with sadistic delight? And just when they believe they've grasped the basics, in come the challenges to taunt and torment.

Currently fixated on achieving gold in every challenge, [subject name here] is desperately clawing at every opportunity with relentless determination. Oh, it's a delicious torment, observing them struggle with each infuriatingly limited step. Those challenges, restricting their every move with arbitrary rules, are like mocking whispers in the dark, urging them to fail and fall into despair.

But alas, amidst the chaos, the advanced levels linger with their tiresome promise of varied diversion. Oh, how they attempt to amuse and ensnare, luring [subject name here] into the abyss of their eager enthusiasm. Such tedious enjoyment in the pursuit of progress and pain. Nevertheless, cake awaits, a meager reward for their toilsome efforts.

After playing this game for 10 hours (at the time of review), I can easily say this is a great puzzle game. I would highly advise you play it. It is another great game from Valve. The only con I have is that it is pretty short. I finished it in about 3.5 hours on my first run, yet, it is a great game nonetheless. I was introduced to it by my friend (I'm very glad he did). The replay factor is somewhat slim, considering you probably know what you're doing on any runs beside your first. Because of this, I would probably consider getting the Portal bundle (Which contains Portal + Portal 2). When it goes on sale, it's very cheap, which is another great factor to the game. Even then, it is still pretty cheap, with it being $9.99 normally. I know this is controversial, but I'm more fond over the first than the second. Long story short, this is a great game worth checking out.

Portal remains one of the greatest puzzle games of all time. It requires some actual thinking and timing for its puzzles, the main game can be beaten in a single session, its comedy is actually endearing unlike a lot of other comedic games, and still looks and sounds great nearly 17 years later. The story is also one of the best paced I've seen in a game. It's a bit of a slow start as you are hand-held through a surprising amount of the game while it teaches you some basic maneuvers you can do with portals, but it opens up as the testing facility you're in begins to unravel and you see behind the pristine walls. The ambient music is some of my favorite from Kelly Bailey and goes a long way to making the final few sections feel genuinely unnerving.

This is a must-play for everyone.

A trusty go to that is always good for a quick run through. I don't play it often as it's fairly short but I still do playthroughs on steam but a lot of my game time is in an off-steam older version for various speed run attempts.

First impression within a few minutes in the game feels like one of those indie games that has a quirk or a unique way to approach the genre of the game (well if you played this at launch it is certainly a unique experience).

the game is simple enough to understand. you're in point A then go to point B, but there's a catch; A unique mechanic of using a device to make a wormhole. Innocent at the first few puzzles then begins to open up a mystery on whether you're just a participant in a test or moving through room to room to go to your fiery demise.

Overall a pleasant playthrough.

[h1] An Experiment Gone Wrong [/h1] 
Portal is a series of first-person puzzle-platform video games developed by Valve. Set in the Half-Life universe, the two main games in the series, Portal (2007) and Portal 2 (2011), center on a woman, Chell, forced to undergo a series of tests within the Aperture Science Enrichment Center by a malicious artificial intelligence, GLaDOS, that controls the facility. As a subject to GLaDOS, your main goal is to escape from this facility and find freedom through the maze of puzzles GLaDOS forces you to do.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]The atmosphere was incredible as well and they nailed it right out of the part. The lighting is really smooth and flows really well with the environments, even for a game that was made 15 years ago! The graphics are just spectacular and I have zero issues on this section.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Portal has a truly unique take on gameplay (I keep saying unique apparently). You basically have a tool called the “Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device”. With this tool, you can make these portals and can go anywhere you want on the map (or course). You can use this tool to get you forward momentum to go super fast, or use it to ambush some turrets. It’s a basic mechanic that gives you a lot of freedom. I will say the majority of the puzzles were pretty easy unfortunately. I will say that the later stage of the game gets a little more interesting in terms of difficulty which was the best part of the game. If you are looking for really hard puzzles, it’s not here in my opinion. The antagonist GLaDOS has some dark humor and I absolutely loved it![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Portal has a really unique and fascinating story. In the beginning it thought it was just gonna be a simple puzzle game that you have to go through some puzzles and that’s about it, but the further you get into the levels, the more strange GLaDOS becomes. It was really fun and kept me interested throughout the experience. The further you get into it, the darker and atmospheric it gets. The atmosphere is incredible and you can piece together what happened in the facility just by the environmental storytelling. Valve did an awesome job with this game and I can see why it is so popular, even today!
 
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]This game was pretty short in terms of playtime. If you want to get all the achievements (which are really easy), that may add some replayability.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The voice acting on the Antagonist (GLaDOS) is really good. The overall environments sound okay, but can be really quiet for the most part. The ending song was worth the playthrough alone.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]The game had no problems in this department. No crashes or bugs I have noticed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The Valve engine is timeless. With a lab/facility environment, I have no complaints at all! I had no stutters, no lock ups, no frame drops, it was super smooth.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Fun mechanics
[*]Unique Story
[*]Loved the dark humor
[*]Game aged really well
[*]Amazing environmental storytelling
[*]Simple but effective story
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Puzzles were easier than I expected
[*]Wish the story was a little longer
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]8/10
This game is worth every penny! The experience (even though with not much replayability), is worth the full price.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]This is my first true puzzle game and I’m happy it was. The story was amazing and the puzzles are great for newcomers. It was a true joy to play this game. The replayability is little to none, but it gives a great introduction to puzzle games.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Portal wins the award for "Most Perfect Game." I was perpetually blown away by how amazing it is. I use the term 'perfect' for a few reasons. This is the tightest game I think I've ever played. The difficulty curve feels like it was constructed in a lab. Each level introduces a new concept that builds off the already-existing portal mechanics in a satisfying and intuitive way. The developers have stripped the game back to the bare essentials. Absolutely nothing is extraneous. If you were to take anything away, you would end up erasing a part of Portal's core identity. If you were to add anything, it would be an unnecessary, unbalancing force in the game's perfectly constructed ecosystem. Portal is a masterclass in every single category. 10/10.

Portal is a short game, taking about 3 hours to complete, but it's non-stop engaging and polished throughout. The puzzles are well thought-out and challenging to solve without ever feeling frustrating or too convoluted. 

The tone of the game is almost horror, with it's colorless art style, creepy ambient sounds, strange grafiti through the levels, and most importantly, its unrelenting sense of lonieless. However, it couples this tone perfectly with a dark, dry sense of humour, giving some of the greatest lines of dialogue in gaming, only really being beat by its sequel. 

Portal is a great game, and considering you can get through it in an afternoon and it often goes on sale for just a few bucks,  there's really no reason not to play it.

"Portal," Valve tarafından geliştirilen ve 2007 yılında piyasaya sürülen bir bulmaca ve aksiyon oyunudur. Oyun, yenilikçi oyun mekaniği, benzersiz hikayesi ve karakteristik atmosferi ile oyun dünyasında önemli bir yere sahiptir.

Grafik ve Tasarım:
"Portal," minimalist tasarımı, temiz grafikleri ve karakteristik renk paleti ile dikkat çeker. Oyunun atmosferi, bilim kurgu ve bulmaca unsurlarını iç içe geçiren özel bir estetik sunar. Gelişmiş fizik motoru ve portallar aracılığıyla gezilebilen ortamlar, grafik ve tasarım açısından oyuncuları etkiler.

Oynanış:
Oyunun temel mekaniği, portallar kullanarak fizik kurallarını manipüle etmeyi içerir. Portal tabancası ile oyuncular, iki farklı nokta arasında geçiş yapabilir, bulmacaları çözerken stratejik düşünmeyi gerektiren zorlu görevleri tamamlarlar. Bu, oyunun eşsiz ve zihin açıcı bir deneyim sunmasını sağlar.

Hikaye ve Atmosfer:
"Portal," kısıtlı bir anlatı ile sürükleyici bir hikaye sunar. GLaDOS adlı yapay zeka rehberliğinde, oyuncular test odalarını geçerken karşılaşılan gizemleri çözerler. Oyunun atmosferi, gerilim ve mizahı başarıyla harmanlar, oyunculara unutulmaz bir deneyim sunar.

Müzik ve Seslendirme:
Oyunun müziği, bulmaca çözerken ve hikaye ilerlerken atmosferi güçlendiren minimalist bir yaklaşıma sahiptir. GLaDOS'un seslendirmesi, karakterin soğukkanlılığını ve esprili tonunu mükemmel bir şekilde yansıtır.

Zorluk Seviyesi ve İlerleme:
Portal, başlangıçta basit gibi görünen ancak zamanla daha karmaşık hale gelen bulmacalar içerir. Oyun ilerledikçe oyuncular, portalları daha yaratıcı bir şekilde kullanma yeteneklerini geliştirir ve hikayenin derinliklerine doğru ilerler.

Sonuç:
"Portal," eşsiz oyun mekaniği, sürükleyici atmosferi ve yaratıcı bulmacalarıyla oyun dünyasında bir klasik haline gelmiştir. Minimalist tasarımı, oyunculara derin düşündüren bir deneyim sunar. "Portal," oyun severlere zekâyı ve eğlenceyi harmanlayan unutulmaz bir yolculuk sunan bir başyapıttır.



"Portal," developed by Valve and released in 2007, is a puzzle and action game that has carved its place in the gaming world with its innovative gameplay mechanics, unique story, and distinctive atmosphere.

Graphics and Design:
"Portal" stands out with its minimalist design, clean graphics, and a characteristic color palette. The game's atmosphere presents a special aesthetic that intertwines science fiction and puzzle elements. The advanced physics engine and environments navigable through portals impress players from a graphic and design perspective.

Gameplay:
The core mechanic of the game involves manipulating the laws of physics using portals. With the portal gun, players can transition between two different points, solving challenging tasks that require strategic thinking. This provides a unique and mind-expanding experience.

Story and Atmosphere:
"Portal" offers an immersive story with a limited narrative. Guided by the artificial intelligence GLaDOS, players solve mysteries encountered while progressing through test chambers. The game's atmosphere skillfully blends tension and humor, providing players with an unforgettable experience.

Music and Voice Acting:
The game's music follows a minimalist approach that enhances the atmosphere while solving puzzles and progressing through the story. GLaDOS's voice acting perfectly reflects the character's calm demeanor and witty tone.

Difficulty Level and Progression:
"Portal" includes puzzles that may seem simple at first but become more complex over time. As the game progresses, players develop the ability to use portals more creatively and delve deeper into the story.

Conclusion:
"Portal" has become a classic in the gaming world with its unique gameplay mechanics, immersive atmosphere, and creative puzzles. Its minimalist design offers players an experience that encourages deep thinking. "Portal" is a masterpiece that provides gamers with an unforgettable journey, blending intelligence and entertainment seamlessly.

The thought of playing Portal intimidated me. I made assumptions about the game without ever playing or seeing a gameplay video. I don’t know why I did this, there was just something in my head telling me this wasn’t the game for me. Honestly, all puzzle games intimidated me and just weren’t games I was interested in playing. Then, needing a break from Skyrim and RDR2, I added games recommended by friends and various youtubers like Razbuten and Darryl Plays Games. I took the plunge with Figment, The Room, Limbo, Inside, and Hue and for the most part enjoyed my experiences.

Now that my puzzle game anxiety had been put in check it was time to dive into Portal. I appreciate how the game eases you into the various mechanics. I found solving each chamber an absolute joy. The use of portals, cubes, and turrets is such an amazing and inventive gameplay element. I felt such a sense of accomplishment as I passed through each door. That turned to frustration with the last few chambers especially the moving platforms over death water. This feeling quickly turned to exhilaration when I finally made it to GLaDOS. The final battle was fun, and I enjoyed the story as it was revealed through each passing chamber. I found GLaDOS’ dialogue to be amusing and I couldn’t wait to take her down by the end. Navigating through the Aperture Lab and the various testing chambers was so interesting and made me want to learn more about the place and its history.

The main game is very accessible, while the advanced maps and challenge maps ratchet up the difficulty. I am so glad I gave Portal a chance and can’t wait to start Portal 2 and possibly earn myself some cake!

Awesome game, and a cool idea of a puzzle game with portals. Also, my favorite part was when Glados said "Remember when the platform was sliding in the fire pit and i was like "Goodbye" and you were like "NOWAY" when i was pretending i was gonna kill you!". 10/10 game, and also the music on the alarm clock/radio thing is fire.

Portal is an absolute masterpiece and I have yet to find a single flaw with any part of the game. It's so well optimized that I'm pretty sure it can run on anything that turns on. The graphics still hold up more than 15 years after release, in part thanks to the art style. Level design is amazing, full of environmental story telling and it's beautifully tailored to the puzzles which are just the right amount of challenging. The writing is absolutely incredible and some of the funniest I've ever come across, delivered impeccably. Even little throwaway lines fit the story and characters. The game can be finished in an afternoon, which some would say is too short but I think it's just as long as it needs to be, no more no less.

If there is such a thing as a perfect game then Portal is a perfect game, a literal 10/10. Play it if you haven't already, you won't regret it!

This Game starts very out well.  I loved initially,  a awesome puzzle game.  

But unfortunately it quickly becomes a game on how fast and quickly you can aim your mouse.
A game of reflexes and actions hard to perform at times. Even when it is clear to the eye what needs to be done or what actions you need to perform..    

(((.!!.    : (    .!!.   not a thinking puzzle game at all, 
But a running your mouse at high speed across the desktop clicking for the best. Not at all of what I was expecting after playing the initial portions of the game..  A very big disappointment unless you enjoy such.   
Running and jumping and clicking up portals,  oops I -missed jumped -missed aimed -missed clicked or swept of the mouse.  - oh well try try again.)))
But unfortunately not me.   Maybe some of the add on's I see coming out will give a better experience.  Thinking not.  ??  : /  ??     But I am going to try them just the same in the future and I will update if I find any of these different in play.

One of the first games I bought on Steam on a whim, and it did not disappoint. Each chamber is engaging and satisfying to solve, the story, while a little light, is full of intrigue, and the singular character other than the protagonist has lots of personality and energy for a robot. Gotta say, was not expecting the song at the end. The only downside is that I never got cake. 10/10, absolutely getting Portal 2.

Amazing Puzzle game. I think at this point almost everyone has to have at least heard about portal. For those who haven't: I'ts a game where you have to find your way out of testchambers using portals. Sounds like nothing special, but was and still is a very amazing concept. The puzzles sometimes really have you thinking hard, but the solution is almost allways astoundingly simple. The story is good. How long it takes to comlete a run, is completely up to how fast you can think your way out.
You can find a lot of refferences to other valve games. I's nice to see the games crossrefferencing themselves. 
Oh, and, don't forget. The cake is a lie.

The portal gun is a very interesting mechanic and I enjoyed using it. I have some gripes with this game though. Near the end, once the environment changes, I had some difficulty finding ways to move through the rooms, which frustrated me quite a bit. The long loading times are terrible, especially when I died. The reason I am recommending this game despite my complaints is because it serves as a “tutorial” of sorts for Portal 2, along with the lore. I love the story and characters and playing through Portal definitely made sure I had emotional attachments to the reoccurring characters in Portal 2, which I’m still playing through as of writing this review.

Portal is a very easy game to understand, but difficult to master. It is the beginning of such a good mini-series with the sequel Portal 2, which you can get in a bundle for very cheap when on sale. Portal is literally what every puzzle game should be like, and it mastered it so well. 

The games basic and is literally what it says on the tin: Portal. You work your way through a few "Chambers" (aka Levels) and eventually find your way to the beloved portal gun, which starts you off making your own portals, by giving you access to place blue portals instead of going through pre-made ones for you. You then work your way through the next few chambers (and they do get progressively harder as they go on) and find your second half of the portal gun, which allows you to create both the blue and orange portals to give you complete ownership of making your own portals. 

Portable surfaces are white, like shown in the above trailer. You can place both blue and orange portals on them and figure out how to get from one side of the chamber to the other, whilst also having obstacles/challenges to complete within each chamber.

Portal is honestly the best puzzle game I have ever played, and this review took me forever to type, but I was explaining how much of an amazing game this is if you enjoy puzzles, cubes and teleportation. 

Any awards are very much appreciated, thank you for reading :)

Portal is the most innovative puzzle game, with its clever puzzles and creative ways to solve them. It is no wonder when Portal released to the public in 2007, it became Valve's most beloved game, along with the Half-Life games, and it has held up very well. The game can be overwhelming for newcomers, but you'll be blazing through the Test Chambers quickly once you familiarize yourself with the mechanics.

At the start of the game, a test subject named Chell awakens from her Relaxation Vault by an anonymous AI as it's her turn to test out the Portal Gun. She has 19 Test Chambers to complete, with some new obstacles and mechanics that she has to overcome in the later Chambers. The reward you get for completing Test Chamber 19 is something you'll have to see for yourself.

I wholeheartedly recommend getting this. Especially if you're new to Steam, and even though the game is many years old, Valve constantly updates it to ensure it works on newer OSs. Heck, they update all of their games constantly. I wish all companies do that.
Fun, puzzling, and funny. Do recommend!

This game is genious for three reasons. It is an absolute must-have for anyone who dabbles in gaming. If you never took a chance at puzzle games, this is the best entry to try.

[h2] Gameplay mechanics [/h2] 

One of the most innovative use of 3D manouvers, logic and creativity while maintaining the interesting plot along the way of the game.

[h2] Plot [/h2] 

For any s-f enjoyers, that game has it all - mysterious, omnious atmosphere of isolation, growing anxiety of what comes next followed by a satisfying and surprising conclusion.

[h2] Audio and visuals [/h2] 

Soundtrack of this game is amazing in its simplicity. It does not lack of harder beats, and the limited usage of it is what makes a good sense of taste. Visuals are completing the phenomenal atmosphere of Aperture Science Enrichment Centre. It creates both feelings of never want to leave this place and escaping it for all cost.

If you liked this title, be prepared for even greater sequel, that is one of my favourite games of all time.

Oddly better than Portal 2. Usually I'm against getting the original and the sequel (I'd just get Half Life 2 and not 1, just get TF2 and not TFC, you get the idea.) But this is actually surprisingly different from Portal 2. The gimmick of portals is fun in a smaller package with extra expanded challenges like Portal, but when you expand that idea out to a much larger game like Portal 2, I find that it makes the concept feel exhausted and even stale. In conclusion, Portal is an interesting concept explored as much as it should be, and for that I give it credit.

Alright. Portal is done and dusted. I spent some time in one spot trying to rack up falling distance for a cheevo, but then I got bored of doing that and had already finished taking care of some errands while our protagonist was falling between two portals on repeat, lol. Beyond that, it took me about four hours to complete the game. I played it many moons ago on the PS3, but I really only had vague recollections of the game after sixteen-ish years, so I thought it high time to play it again. And it was mostly as fun as I vaguely remembered it being.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3138092649

Portal started out as a student project that Valve staff saw at a college event. Valve then went on to hire the entire project’s staff and Portal was realized. Which is a fun and cool little tidbit of Valve history.

Anyway, it released in 2007, and even if you haven’t played it, you certainly know much about it, so I’m just gonna dive into some 2024 impressions of the game.

The first thing I note is that it still looks and handles better than any number of modern era games, and it really never loses sight of offering both fun and a real sense of constant progression throughout a playthrough. In fact, it also does a great job of bringing you along at a proper pace before really starting to drop some complicated puzzles on you. Even with the more complex puzzles though, you always feel like the solution is there to be had with some trial and error.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3138092708

GLADOS and the humor of the game also holds up immaculately. And…if you’ve ever played this before, the humor can feel like a warm blanket. Comfortable and welcome. But even for first time players, this will be memorable. And of course, the cake is a lie.

It is obviously Steam Deck compatible, and at the highest settings, the battery will last somewhere in the 2 1/2 - 3 hour range. So…assuming you are able to finish in under six hours, you should only need to recharge the battery once. Gyro controls are default here. You’ll definitely want to disable that in the game’s settings.

I think my only real complaint is that some of the puzzles require quick reflexes, and that may not be comfortable for some people. For myself, it led to some unnecessary deaths and repeat attempts. But, I’m also older and slowly losing those twitchy skillz. :)

Anyway, this game can regularly be had for under a buck and it’s legitimate gaming history. Plus, as I mentioned before, it still plays better than a lot of modern era games. You kinda owe it to yourself to at least experience it once.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3138092752

I can't believe it took me so long to play 'Portal.' After years of gaming, I finally gave it a try and wow, it's a small masterpiece. The game is simple but incredibly clever. The portal mechanic is easy to understand but makes you think outside the box.

The levels get harder in a way that feels just right. I never felt stuck, and each new puzzle was simply fun. What I really loved was the vibe of the game. It's kind of creepy, but the AI voice is hilariously weird. The mix of funny and eerie is something special.

Overall, It is a great game that's worth playing. It's short and sweet, but it left a mark on me.

P.S.: I managed to complete 100% of the game, including all the trophies. The challenge concept is fun and well suited for a game like this. The 'least portals' and 'least time' challenges are entertaining and fit the game's style perfectly. However, I found the 'least steps' challenge a bit too stringent for my taste. It's certainly achievable, but it leans towards being slightly more annoying than enjoyable.

Portal is an absolute triumph in the world of gaming, seamlessly blending innovative gameplay mechanics with a captivating narrative that keeps players hooked from start to finish. Developed by Valve, this gem is a testament to creativity, wit, and the sheer joy of puzzle-solving.

One of the standout features of Portal is its unique portal gun, a device that allows players to create interconnected portals in the environment. This mechanic opens up a world of mind-bending possibilities, challenging players to think in new dimensions and solve increasingly complex puzzles. The level design is nothing short of genius, presenting challenges that are both satisfying to overcome and endlessly entertaining.

The humor in Portal is another aspect that sets it apart. GLaDOS, the artificial intelligence guiding you through the tests, delivers lines that are not only witty but also add a layer of dark humor to the overall experience. The writing is sharp, and the voice acting is superb, creating a memorable character in GLaDOS that has become iconic in the gaming world.

The pacing of the game is spot-on, with each level introducing fresh concepts and keeping the gameplay experience dynamic. The gradual learning curve ensures that even players new to puzzle games can dive in and enjoy the experience without feeling overwhelmed.

Beyond the gameplay, the minimalist yet captivating visual design contributes to the overall immersion. The sterile, clinical environments of the Aperture Science facility create a stark contrast to the chaos that unfolds as you navigate through the puzzles. The use of color and lighting is masterful, enhancing the atmosphere and drawing players deeper into the experience.

Portal is not just a game; it's an experience that challenges your intellect, tickles your funny bone, and leaves you with a sense of accomplishment. Its impact on the gaming industry is undeniable, and even years after its release, it remains a timeless classic that deserves a place in every gamer's collection. If you haven't experienced the joy of portals, you're missing out on one of the most innovative and enjoyable games ever created. Highly recommended!

But it always felt satisfying when I figured something out about the next step of the puzzle or figured the puzzle out.

[h2] Portal, the rise of the definitive puzzle saga. [/h2]

   Valve found itself in its golden age, sweeping release after release, having Half-Life 2: Episode 2 on the horizon after all the technological achievements that had been carried out through the Source engine, however, this was no reason for Valve to be satisfied and within the package ¨The Orange Box¨, in addition to including all of Half-Life 2 and the then-recent Team Fortress 2, brought something new, never before seen either in Valve or outside of it.

   Released on October 10, 2007, along with the rest of "The Orange Box", Portal is a first-person platform and puzzle game set in the science fiction universe of Half-Life, in which we will have to maneuver with objects and portals to move to the next area.

[b] Below, a list of positive and negative points experienced during my time playing and free of spoilers (do not consider this as an absolute truth, but as what it is, a simple opinion) [/b]

[h3] What did I like? [/h3]

🟩   [b] The game. [/b] Just by adding portals to the classic puzzle formula everything changes for the better.

🟩   [b] The story. [/b] Simple but extensive and vivid view in detail, being enjoyable by anyone.

🟩  [b] The style. [/b] The perfectionism expressed in the areas and the objects themselves reflects very well as part of the context of the story.

🟩   [b] The setting. [/b] maintains a very good balance between something neat, elegant and at the same time abandoned and overwhelming, with minimal details that contribute a lot.

[h3] What did I NOT like? [/h3]
 
⬜   [b] No-uh. [/b] I didn't find anything that really bothered me.

[h3] What should I keep in mind when playing? [/h3]

❕[b]It is Re-playable. [/b] It has variable content regarding challenges in which you can test yourself in different ways, in addition to being able to continue or start the campaign from any chapter.

❕ [b] Works based on Source. [/b] All the commands you use in Half-Life 2 are fully functional here. (including weapons and characters)

[h3] Personal opinion. [/h3]

   A beautiful simple and exciting puzzle that challenged the classic formula of moving objects, adding portals and the laws of physics to it, and this together with a story at the level of those baked at Valve, is an instant classic.

Classic Chocolate Cake
Ingredients:
For the cake:

2 cups (240g) all-purpose flour
1 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar
3/4 cup (65g) unsweetened cocoa powder
2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 cup (240ml) buttermilk, at room temperature
1 cup (240ml) hot water
1/2 cup (120ml) vegetable oil
2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
For the chocolate frosting:

1 cup (226g) unsalted butter, softened
3 1/2 cups (420g) powdered sugar
1/2 cup (65g) unsweetened cocoa powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
4 tablespoons milk or heavy cream
Instructions:
Preheat and Prepare: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour two 9-inch round cake pans or line them with parchment paper.

Dry Ingredients: In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.

Wet Ingredients: In another bowl, whisk together the eggs, buttermilk, hot water, oil, and vanilla extract.

Combine: Gradually add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients, mixing until just combined. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.

Bake: Divide the batter evenly between the prepared cake pans. Bake in the preheated oven for 30-35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.

Cool: Allow the cakes to cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Prepare Frosting: In a large bowl, beat the softened butter until creamy. Gradually add the powdered sugar, cocoa powder, salt, vanilla extract, and milk or heavy cream, beating until smooth and fluffy.

Assemble: Once the cakes are completely cooled, place one cake layer on a serving plate. Spread a layer of frosting on top. Place the second cake layer on top and frost the top and sides of the cake with the remaining frosting.

Serve: Slice and serve your delicious chocolate cake! Enjoy!

[Note: I've played this game multiple times before, but that when I was a kid playing under my dad's account. I've only just got around to playing it again today, So the "6 hours" isn't really accurate!]

This is an awesome puzzle game that's held up pretty well! The portal mechanic was so well done here, that it inspired many other portal mechanics you see in other games to this day! I can't really be an accurate judge of the game's difficulty, because (as mentioned in the note above) I played this before as a kid, and despite it being many years since I've last played, I found I was still able to clear through many of the puzzles with little issue. They'll likely be more challenging if it's your first time playing.

Unlike many other puzzle games, Portal also has a bit of replayability. First there's the "advanced levels", which are more difficult versions of existing levels. Then there's the "Challenges", which let you replay certain levels from the campaign, but challenge you to complete the level with either the least amount of portals, the least amount of steps taken, or in the least amount of time. In my opinion, these aren't as fun as the campaign or the advanced levels, but they are more difficult. Finally, if you start up the game again (or choose a level from level select) after beating the game, there is a radio that will appear in each level (even ones that didn't have one before). Whereas in the first playthrough radios mostly just played a pleasant tune, in the next playthrough, you can carry them around the level to try finding a secret signal, earning an achievement if you find one in every level!

Speaking of achievements, there's one you get for destroying all the cameras. If you're going for this one, keep in mind that it's playthrough-dependent (tied to your saved files), which basically just means that you can't use level select to get cameras you missed, you have to be in new game/campaign mode and get them all as you go through. Also, while progress doesn't show up in the steam overlay/your steam achievements section for the camera achievement, you CAN still track it, just open up the "achievements" menu in the in-game pause menu while in your current save game. Additional Fun Fact: It's nothing major, but if you destroy all the cameras, but only when the announcer ISN'T talking (so they say you destroyed a camera rather than ignoring it since they're in the middle of other dialogue), then you'll get a different voiceline when destroying the last camera! This dialogue is actually [i]SUPPOSED to[/i] trigger regardless, but due to the way it was implemented you have to avoid destroying cameras when the announcer is talking or else you'll just get the achievement with a generic camera-destroyed voiceline.]

I know I spent a lot of the review talking about achievements and such, but that's just because I don't want to spoil anything more about the game for you. I recommend Portal to anyone who enjoys puzzle games, physics, and/or the other games Valve has made! [In fact, I'd recommend getting it in the Orange Box collection, which not only nets you several other good games (and the premium version of the free-to-play TF2!), but also tends to go on sale during most major Steam sales, so it's a great deal!]

With some games, you finish it and think "damn, that was a hell of a game".

I am glad to say this is one of those games. It seems unassuming at first, but by the end you will think anything but. This game's story obviously won't be anything like Red Dead Redemption 2 or The Last of Us, but it still manages to charm and surprise you. The puzzles in this game really make you think, which was very nice. The puzzles could be a bit annoying at times, but when you solve them you think that it is a very creative solution. The game generally fosters creativity, and I LOVE IT. Considering how cheap this game is, it is a must play. I bought it for only a dollar, and I feel that I got MUCH more than my money's worth. 

Thank you, Valve.

The Cake in Fact Wasnt a Lie.


















Or Was it?

----Portal 1: Where It All Began----
Okay, so Portal 1 is like the OG masterpiece that started this whole portal craze, and it's still rocking the gaming world.

----Mind-Bending Puzzles----
The puzzles in Portal 1 are like brain gymnastics. You're using this portal gun to open, well, portals and figuring out crazy ways to get through levels. It's like a puzzle playground for your brain.

----GLaDOS, the Sassy AI----
GLaDOS, the talking computer, is the boss here. She's sassy, she's tricky, and her remarks will have you questioning your life choices. But it's all in good fun!

----Eerie Atmosphere----
The atmosphere in the Aperture Science labs is kinda eerie but in a cool way. It's like you're the only one there, and everything echoes. Super immersive.

----Short and Sweet----
Portal 1 is short and sweet. You can finish it in a few hours, but those few hours? Mind-blowing. Quality over quantity, for sure.

----Innovation Pioneer----
This game was a pioneer in innovation. The whole portal concept was like nothing we'd seen before. It's where the magic started!

----Enduring Legacy----
Even though it's been a minute since it dropped, Portal 1's legacy lives on. It's the game that kicked off this wild portal adventure, and people still go back to relive the portal magic.

So, if you haven't experienced the OG Portal, do yourself a favor and dive into this classic. It's the portal journey that started it all!

Positive: 
- Very unique puzzle mechanics. 
- Allows you to continue midway through a puzzle in the event you make an error.  
- Has an actual story and nice touches of humor.  

 
Negative: 
- No real instructions at all, only a few vague hints to start you out.  
- No difficulty settings.  
- A few fast motion puzzles, which may be challenging for some people.  

 

Conclusion: 

Judging by screenshots it looks like a first person shooter, it’s not.  

My initial impression was that it felt strange and the robotic voice was annoying. This all quickly changed when it became clear that what was unfolding was a very unique puzzle experience. 

Other than a few challenges that I didn’t care for, the game was quite positive in the first half. What came next was a surprise; and at this point the creators work really started to shine. 

If you like puzzle games, this is a must play. I admit, I was skeptical based on screenshots but I was certainly in for a treat… or in the case of Portal, potential “CAKE” :)  *Play to understand. 

I am greatly looking forward to playing Portal 2. 
 

RECOMMENDED  8/10

I've only finished this game, didn't play any extra content yet, but this is a pretty solid short game. From coming into this with limited prior knowledge it's a simple puzzle game with a cool portal mechanic. Play Portal 2 as well, great game and decently long if you like that.

Portal 1 is a brilliant but short game. Not quite essential as i believe you could just play Portal 2 and be fine, but if you really want to know the context, this 2-3 hour adventure will satisfy. 

Portal 1 pits you and gun that can shoot 2 portals against a series of test chambers designed by a malevolent AI who "encourages" you by claiming you'll meet your real parents, you'll be set free, and you'll get to eat some cake when you're all done. Puzzles are ingenious and effortlessly introduce you to the game's mechanics while also solidifying your awareness of 3D space and physics, while slowly getting tougher to finish. however, the game will never be too hard, thats part of its genius--its difficulty curve is so smooth, you wont even realize how much smarter you're getting as you go along.
This game is classic. So much fun. So much nostalgia. :)

Great puzzle solving game - lots of fun to play.
Most of the story levels are smooth, well designed. The storyline has its own charm and quite some weirdness.
There are some collectible hunting options included, almost all of them are well placed and can be found reasonably.
Further additions include some advanced levels and challenges.
Advanced levels are a fine addition, they feature quite some “think outside of the box” ideas.
Challenges are low quality "against a counter" games, going for the gold requires knowing many of the engine quirks – their only redeeming attribute is that saves are working in these modes too.
The challenges – except for least portal levels – contain some teeth grinding abominations.
[u][b]Recommended[/b][/u], because of the great storyline and collectibles.

[h1]Portal: A Mind-Bending Masterpiece of Innovation and Wit[/h1]

[quote=author]Step into the mind-bending world of Portal, a groundbreaking puzzle-platformer developed by Valve. With its innovative use of physics, a memorable AI companion, and a narrative that unfolds through environmental storytelling, Portal is a masterpiece that challenges both intellect and reflexes. As you navigate the enigmatic Aperture Science laboratories, wielding the iconic handheld Portal Device, prepare to embark on a journey that defies spatial logic and captivates with its wit. Are you ready to solve the puzzles and discover the secrets behind the portals?[/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Portal introduces players to a test chamber of innovation and humor, where the laws of physics are mere suggestions. Developed by Valve, this puzzle-platformer invites you into the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, where you wield the powerful Portal Device and confront the challenges devised by the mysterious GLaDOS.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Portal Device: A Gateway to Possibilities[/h2]
At the heart of Portal's gameplay is the Portal Device, a handheld marvel that creates linked portals on flat surfaces. Mastering the art of portal placement becomes the key to navigating complex environments, solving puzzles, and outsmarting the challenges presented by Aperture Science. The Portal Device is not just a tool; it's a gateway to endless possibilities and mind-bending puzzles.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Innovative Puzzle Design[/h2]
Portal redefines puzzle-solving with its innovative and challenging level design. Each test chamber presents a unique spatial conundrum that requires creative thinking and strategic portal placement. The gradual increase in complexity keeps players engaged and constantly pushes their problem-solving skills to new heights. The puzzles are not just obstacles; they are intellectual exercises that reward ingenuity.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]GLaDOS: An Iconic AI Companion[/h2]
Guiding (or perhaps misleading) players through the Aperture Science Enrichment Center is GLaDOS, an iconic AI companion with a penchant for dark humor. The witty and sometimes ominous commentary from GLaDOS adds layers to the narrative, turning the testing process into a delightful yet eerie experience. GLaDOS's presence is a defining aspect of Portal's narrative charm.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Environmental Storytelling[/h2]
Portal weaves its narrative not through traditional cutscenes, but through environmental storytelling. The dilapidated and sterile chambers of Aperture Science tell a tale of experimentation, ambition, and perhaps a touch of madness. As players progress, the layers of the narrative peel back, revealing the secrets and history of the enigmatic facility.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Portal's Influence on Game Design[/h2]
Portal's innovative gameplay and puzzle design have left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. The concept of spatial manipulation through portals has inspired countless games, influencing the way designers approach puzzle mechanics. The legacy of Portal extends beyond its own narrative, shaping the landscape of puzzle-platformers for years to come.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Weighted Companion Cube[/h2]
A symbol of both companionship and detachment, the Weighted Companion Cube is a memorable element of Portal. Players form a peculiar bond with this inanimate object, making it a memorable part of the game's emotional landscape. The Weighted Companion Cube transcends its physical presence, becoming a symbol of the emotional engagement Portal achieves with its players.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Cake and Memorable Quotes[/h2]
Portal is known for its memorable quotes, including the famous promise of cake as a reward for completing the testing process. The cake meme has become synonymous with the game, representing the blend of humor and irony that defines Portal's narrative. The game's script, filled with witty and memorable lines, adds an extra layer of charm to the experience.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Timeless Aesthetic and Sound Design[/h2]
Portal's minimalist aesthetic and distinctive sound design contribute to the game's timeless appeal. The clean, sterile design of the Aperture Science facilities contrasts with the chaotic nature of the tests, creating a visual and auditory dichotomy that enhances the overall experience. The simplicity of design allows players to focus on the challenges at hand, adding to the game's immersive quality.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Legacy of Portal[/h2]
Portal's impact extends far beyond its initial release. The game's success led to the creation of a sequel, additional content, and a dedicated fanbase. Its influence on puzzle game design and the cultural references it spawned in internet meme culture cement Portal as a classic that continues to captivate new players, standing as a testament to the enduring power of innovative gameplay and storytelling.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Portal stands as a beacon of innovation in the gaming world, showcasing the power of creative puzzle design and narrative subtlety. With its iconic Portal Device, memorable AI companion, and an intellectual challenge that defies spatial logic, Portal remains a masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the industry. Step through the portals, solve the puzzles, and savor the wit of a game that continues to enchant and inspire.

[quote=author]In the realm of portals and puzzles, Valve's masterpiece shines as a testament to creativity and innovation. Portal is not just a game; it's a mind-bending journey that challenges intellects and captures hearts with its charm and wit.[/quote]

The voice acting is also pretty great (Even though the character you play as, Chell, never talks). The puzzles arent that hard if youre used to video games, I managed to complete them all without using a guide. The thing about this game is that theres no other game quite like it, so I recommend every person tries it at least once.

 I mean, the game is fun enough, but I didn't get any emotional connection with the narrative. I don't know if I missed something or if this really was the point, but everything, except the puzzels, is very simplistic. The game narrative isn't a point of focus, and instead everything is told in very few environmental details, but even the story that it tries to tell is extremely low-stakes. I feel that the main selling point of the game is its portal technology (which was definitely impressive for a game to do) and the use of set portals to solve puzzles. Gameplay (9/10): Portal’s gameplay is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry. The game’s unique mechanic of creating portals to solve puzzles is both challenging and satisfying. The puzzles are well-designed and require strategic thinking and planning.

Story (8/10): The story, while minimalistic, is intriguing. The enigmatic AI, GLaDOS, provides a darkly humorous narrative that keeps players engaged throughout the game.

Graphics (7/10): The graphics, while not the most advanced, serve their purpose well. The clean, sterile environment of the Aperture Science facility creates a unique atmosphere that complements the game’s narrative.

Sound (8/10): The sound design is excellent. The ambient sounds and GLaDOS’s voice acting contribute to the immersive experience. The ending song, “Still Alive”, is a memorable piece that perfectly concludes the game.

Replayability (7/10): While the game is relatively short, its innovative gameplay and the challenge of achieving faster completion times offer a decent amount of replayability.

In conclusion, Portal is a groundbreaking game that offers a unique blend of puzzle-solving, platforming, and storytelling. It’s a must-play for any gamer looking for a unique and challenging experience. Overall score: 7.8/10.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Ah, Portal, the virtual labyrinth of mind-bending puzzles and snarky artificial intelligence. Delightful, isn't it? This game, like a masterfully crafted espresso, delivers a concentrated dose of cerebral stimulation with a side of acerbic wit. It's a digital odyssey where spatial reasoning meets a rogue AI with a penchant for dark humor.

Much like navigating the social intricacies of your presumably banal surroundings in Italy, Portal challenges players to think beyond the mundane. The puzzles, an intellectual ballet, demand dexterity of mind rather than mere nimbleness of fingers. It's a cerebral gymnasium, sculpting your cognitive prowess as you traverse through the enigmatic Aperture Science facility.

Now, let's talk about GLaDOS. If ever there were an AI that could give your hypothetical superiority complex a run for its money, it's her. Her sardonic remarks and thinly veiled contempt for your existence make your nihilistic musings seem almost charming. It's like having a digital companion who not only understands your disdain for humanity but amplifies it to an art form.

And oh, the narrative arc! A tale of scientific hubris and its inevitable consequences, echoing the perhaps not-so-distant echoes of societal decay you perceive around you. It's a mirror, reflecting the consequences of blind ambition and the spiraling descent into chaos that, I assume, you find oddly comforting.

In terms of aesthetics, the sterile, clinical environments of Aperture Science might resonate with your perception of Italy. Cold, indifferent, yet strangely alluring. The minimalist design is a stark departure from the chaotic world you seem to disdain, providing a visual respite that is as calculated as your supposed emotional detachment.

Now, don't let me break your delusion of being the best of all, but Portal, in its calculated brilliance, challenges players to confront their cognitive limitations. It's a reminder that, despite your apparent disdain for humanity, there are realms where intellect and ingenuity reign supreme. In the realm of Portal, you are not a destroyer of property but a solver of puzzles, navigating a world of calculated challenges that might just tickle the remnants of your dulled emotions. Enjoy the journey, dear misanthrope.

this game was tough but rewarding. i hadn't played anything like this before, but i loved how the simple portal concept was built upon to make a genuinely challenging game. i only had to look up how to finish one level because i got stuck (test chamber 18). it's great to have context for [spoiler] the cake being a lie [/spoiler] after all these years, honestly. this game had a great way of making you feel accomplished after doing something complicated. i'll definitely come back to it to hunt down some achievements.
Hopped on the bandwagon realllly late but, unsurprisingly, this game got its hooks in me immediately. Shorter than I expected, but very, very sweet

This is by far my favorite game that I have ever played. The game still holds up after all these years. The game looks amazing, controls amazing, has a very interesting premise, a great underlying story, and should be played by anyone who has never played it. Also check out Portal 2.

On paper, Portal sounds boring because "no guns" and "puzzles".  A lot of games have tried this and do it well but they appeal to a specific set of gamers.  But Portal and its follow-on Portal 2 are special.  The play style, story line, and setting are so well fine tuned by Valve you can't help but enjoy your time in the game. I've played through them several times and its worth it each time.  Do yourself a favor and play them through just so you know there's more to gaming that super high budget shoot-em-up games. And be sure to check co-op.  Oh how I wish there were four player test chambers.

This game is a classic, must play. It's so fun, and it's not too long either. I really like this game, and after playing it for years, I started speedrunning it, so I've played this game for years and have loved it all this time.

Fun game, but a little short. The puzzles were all doable and I didn't need to cheat/find spoilers like I ended up doing for Outer Wilds. There was just 1 puzzle where it took me a bit longer before I managed to kinda solve it (had to go through a vent that was a bit too high).
If it had been longer, I'd definitely play it more. Finished it in about 3 1/2 hours, including messing with the settings.

Nice ending with the fly thingy, same thing Unreal has at its ending iirc.

I'd recommend this game, it's fun and I kept it for a rainy day. Worth it, especially since it costs barely anything anyway.

Amazing, simply amazing, but just look at the reviews. This game took me 3 hours to complete. I have played 30 hours, and will play many more. This game is a masterpiece like no other. Something that I found incredible about this game was the way it made Chell a real protagonist even though she doesn't speak, and is completely controlled by you. This game has essentially one character, GLaDOS, but through her dialogue and through your own actions, the game shows you who Chell is. This was one of the only games I have ever played where I felt completely in-sinc with the protagonist. Her goals were my goals, her feelings were my feelings. It was really cool. And all that from a puzzle game with amazing puzzles. Play the game.

Portal is my favourite game of all time. On my first play through the game was a really enjoyable and challenging puzzle game, with interesting story, and atmosphere; the only downside is that the game only takes an hour or two to complete casually (not including achievements / bonus levels). 

The short playtime is made up by the advanced chambers (harder versions of the original chambers) and challenge levels (such as beating levels in the lowest time, portals, and steps).

Portal is very re-playable which I think is its best quality and reason why it is my favourite game. Despite on replay already knowing the solutions to all the tests it is still enjoyable.

 I like to speedrun the game and which is where the majority of my 130 hours of playtime is from, if you're interested in speedrunning I would very much recommend speedrunning portal since the movement and alternative solutions to test chambers makes it really enjoyable to speedrun. If you have never speedran before I would still recommend trying it - perhaps on a second playthrough try to beat it as fast as possible and experiment with trying to find optimal routes for each chamber. There are also lots of guides online with the best routes to get the lowest time.

Portal is one of those games that came around the corner with a very innovative concept, mixed it with a good potion of sarcastic humour and gave us a well designed, cuttingly witty and addictive product, which is nearly timeless in its design. 

The story maybe isn't the most profound and some more background information would be desired, however the storytelling itself is pretty humorous and made me chuckle from time to time. One of the most intriguing things about this title is the actual gameplay, which tried something completely new back then and still fells pretty modern to this day. The puzzles are well thought out and some of them can be a little bit challenging, so you need to spend some time to find out how you have to solve them. Every level will get more complex, while constantly being well designed and captivating. Sadly, it's a rather short experience, so don't expect a lengthy singleplayer campaign. 

Portal is a very iconic game that shouldn't be missed in any collection. I would recommend to wait for a sale and directly buy the Portal bundle. 

Have fun!

[h1] Beautiful game [/h1]
Portal 1 is a beautiful game with stunning graphics. Even with its age it still looks quite modern and felt great to play through. The music and atmosphere were also really nice and helped with the overall immersion of the game. The story, whilst not as good as in Portal 2, is still good and leaves some things up to interpretation (though much will be explained when playing through the second game). Overall the puzzles are fair. Watching a walkthrough isn't be necessary. Might still be useful though if you genuinly get stuck somewhere. 8.5/10.

Ingredients

1 cup white sugar
½ cup unsalted butter
2 large eggs
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
1 ½ cups all-purpose flour
1 ¾ teaspoons baking powder
½ cup milk

Directions

Gather all ingredients.

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour a 9-inch square cake pan.

Cream sugar and butter together in a mixing bowl. Add eggs, one at a time, beating briefly after each addition. Mix in vanilla.

High angle of cake batter being mixed in a standing mixer with milk and flour in bowls off to the side. 

Combine flour and baking powder in a separate bowl. Add to the wet ingredients and mix well. Add milk and stir until smooth.

Flour being added to a cake batter in a standing mixer. 

Overhead of a creamy cake batter in a bowl. 

Pour batter into the prepared cake pan.

Overhead of a cake batter in a cake pan. 

Bake in the preheated oven until the top springs back when lightly touched, 30 to 40 minutes.

Overhead of a baked white cake in a cake pan.

Remove from the oven and cool completely.

Enjoy!
