A wonderful, inventive and gloriously fun, well-aged but short game. Portal while only being about 4-5 hours (for the main stuff not including the bonus maps or challenges) was expertly crafted for a puzzling experience. 

Although I did resort to a walkthrough for 1-2 moments, it was only for a small element of the whole puzzle, and didn't take away the fun of flying through portals. 

The last area was good [spoiler]It was very unexpected, while there was foreshadowing through certain elements, (the little siderooms) the rusted down and not-very-safe aesthetic of the final run was a very unique and cool experience. The GLaDOS fight was very entertaining and the I'm still alive song... just so entertaining [/spoiler]


[spoiler] Also the Half-Life references were very fun, I like little easter eggs like that! [/spoiler]

**Introduction:**

Valve's Portal, initially released in 2007 as part of The Orange Box, is a genre-defying masterpiece that revolutionized puzzle-solving in the gaming landscape. This succinct yet impactful game, set within the mysterious confines of Aperture Science, introduces players to the iconic Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, challenging them to rethink spatial relationships in ways never before imagined.

**Gameplay: 5/5**

Portal's gameplay is a triumph of simplicity and ingenuity. The player, armed with the Portal Gun, can create linked portals on surfaces, allowing for instantaneous travel between two points. The puzzles, designed with meticulous care, progressively increase in complexity, forcing players to employ both logical reasoning and creative problem-solving skills. The gradual introduction of new elements, such as energy balls and weighted companion cubes, adds layers to the challenges, creating a consistently engaging experience.

**Narrative: 4.5/5**

Despite its brevity, Portal weaves a compelling narrative that unfolds within the sterile walls of Aperture Science. The enigmatic GLaDOS serves as both a guide and an adversary, delivering witty and sometimes ominous commentary. The minimalist storytelling approach leaves much to the player's interpretation, adding an air of mystery to the overall experience. While the narrative is intriguing, some players may crave a more in-depth exploration of the game's lore.

**Graphics and Sound: 4.5/5**

Portal's visual design strikes a balance between the clinical aesthetics of Aperture Science and the stark, otherworldly environments encountered within the testing chambers. The clean, minimalist visuals contribute to the game's immersive atmosphere. The sound design, particularly the robotic voice of GLaDOS and the soothing yet eerie background music, enhances the overall experience, creating a sense of isolation and intrigue.

**Length and Replayability: 4/5**

Portal's brevity is both a strength and a limitation. The game can be completed in a relatively short time, but the journey is so meticulously crafted that it feels satisfying rather than lacking. The allure of discovering new and more efficient ways to solve puzzles encourages replayability, and the inclusion of advanced challenge maps extends the longevity for those seeking additional complexity.

**Cultural Impact: 5/5**

Portal's influence on the gaming industry is immeasurable. Its innovative mechanics have inspired countless games, and the iconic catchphrases like "The cake is a lie" have become ingrained in gaming culture. Portal's success paved the way for a standalone sequel and cemented its status as one of the most beloved and enduring titles in video game history.

**Conclusion:**

In summary, Portal is a pioneering gem that transcends the constraints of its relatively short runtime. Its groundbreaking gameplay mechanics, coupled with a compelling narrative and minimalist design, have left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. For anyone seeking a unique and intellectually stimulating experience, Portal remains a must-play classic that showcases the power of innovative game design.

Um jogo incrível e nostálgico.

Minha primeira experiência com Portal foi na casa de meu cunhado, onde ele colocou o jogo simplesmente para eu "queimar uns neurônios", e, sério, eu achei o jogo MUITO difícil, mas muito divertido.

Desde então eu já zerei o jogo mais umas 2 vezes e ele sempre consegue me divertir. O desafio é moderado e, pensando na lógica do problema, você consegue passar das fases sem muita dificuldade. Acho que até uma criança pode jogar e aproveitar bem, pois vai fazer ela pensar em ferramentas para solucionar os enigmas e finalizar com chave de ouro "matando" a Gladius.

Enfim, apesar de meio velho e com os gráficos datados (apesar de existirem mods que deixam-no lindo), é um ótimo jogo para passar o tempo e zerar rapidamente (dá para zerar em menos de 2h se você for bom de raciocínio).

[h1]Portal: A Timeless Classic Still Worth Your Time[/h1]

Portal isn't just a game; it's an experience. It's a masterclass in puzzle design, narrative storytelling, and dark humor, all wrapped up in a surprisingly short yet satisfying package. I've had it on my "to-play" list for years, and let me tell you, it was worth the wait.

Sure, the graphics might not be the latest and greatest, but the gameplay is as fresh and innovative today as it was in 2007. The Portal gun, the game's central mechanic, is a marvel of simplicity and ingenuity. It opens up a world of possibilities for creative puzzle-solving, forcing you to think outside the box and utilize the environment in ways you never imagined.

The story, while initially seemingly lighthearted, takes a dark turn as you delve deeper into the bowels of Aperture Science Laboratories. The writing is sharp and witty, perfectly balanced with the unsettling atmosphere of the facility. And let's not forget GLaDOS, the game's AI companion, whose sardonic commentary provides both humor and a chilling sense of unease.

One might think a game from 2007 would feel dated, but that's not the case with Portal. It's a timeless classic that deserves to be played by everyone. The puzzles are challenging yet rewarding, the story is captivating, and the humor is genuinely funny. And if you're unsure about the price, don't worry! Portal often goes on sale for as little as 90 cents during Steam sales. Seriously, what do you have to lose?

So, if you're looking for a unique and unforgettable gaming experience, look no further than Portal. It's a game that will stay with you long after you've finished it, and one that you'll definitely want to revisit again and again.

I heard about this game for years, and wasn't interrested at all by it (I've a strong dislike for "mainstream" media, and thought it was probably overrated).
Recently my mother wanted to try playing videogames, so I searched for games for beginners (to learn the walking controls, how to use the mouse to aim, the REAL basics) and Portal came out in a lot of discussions.
Bought the bundle (Portal 1 & 2) and, sadly too late, realised that [b]only the later has coop. [/b]
Today I told myself : [i]heh, I should try the first, i'm alone in the house and bored, it'll be probably a boring puzzle game but it's better than nothing...[/i]

[h3][b] I WAS SO WRONG, THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE [/b][/h3]

Introduction:
Portal, developed by Valve, is a groundbreaking puzzle-platformer that left an indelible mark on the gaming industry upon its release in 2007. With its unique mechanics, minimalist design, and dark humor, Portal emerged as a captivating experience that defied conventions and set new standards for puzzle games.

Gameplay (9.5/10):
Portal's gameplay revolves around the ingenious concept of using handheld portal devices to create interconnected wormholes on surfaces. This simple yet revolutionary mechanic forms the basis of increasingly complex puzzles as players progress through the Aperture Science Enrichment Center. The game's short length is a testament to its focus on quality over quantity, offering a tight and polished experience that leaves a lasting impression.

Story and Atmosphere (9/10):
Portal introduces players to the mysterious Aperture Science and its AI overseer, GLaDOS. The narrative unfolds as players navigate through a series of test chambers, and the dark humor and sarcastic commentary by GLaDOS create a unique and memorable atmosphere. While the story is relatively brief, the impact it has on players is profound, and the final moments are nothing short of iconic.

Graphics and Sound (8.5/10):
Portal's visual style is minimalist but effective, with clean and sterile environments that complement the clinical nature of the Aperture Science facility. While the graphics may show their age, the game's art design has a timeless quality. The ambient soundtrack, composed by Mike Morasky, adds to the atmosphere, with the iconic "Still Alive" by Jonathan Coulton serving as the perfect conclusion to the game.

Innovation (10/10):
Portal's greatest achievement lies in its innovation. The portal mechanic was groundbreaking at the time, challenging players to think in three dimensions and manipulate space in ways never seen before in gaming. This level of creativity and originality established Portal as a trailblazer in the industry, influencing countless games that followed.

Legacy (10/10):
Portal's impact on the gaming landscape cannot be overstated. It paved the way for a new era of puzzle games and solidified Valve's reputation for pushing boundaries. The game's influence is evident in its sequel, other titles, and even educational programs that use it to teach problem-solving skills.

Conclusion:
Portal is a seminal work that transcends its modest length and simple premise. Its innovative gameplay, witty narrative, and timeless design make it a classic that continues to resonate with players over a decade after its release. Portal not only revolutionized puzzle gaming but left an enduring legacy that will be remembered and celebrated for years to come.

Title: "Portal: A 6/5 Star Odyssey into Ingenious Puzzles and Witty Banter"

Rating: ★★★★★★ (6/5)

Portal, Valve's landmark puzzle game, earns an extra star for its unparalleled brilliance, revolutionizing gameplay and storytelling in the gaming world. The innovative portal mechanics, GLaDOS's witty banter, and the infamous cake meme collectively weave a narrative that transcends mere gaming and transforms into an enduring cultural phenomenon.

The genius lies in the simplicity and complexity interwoven throughout the game. Navigating the Aperture Science Enrichment Center using portals requires a perfect balance of logic and creativity, providing an immersive experience that is both challenging and immensely satisfying.

GLaDOS, the sentient AI, steals the show with her sarcastic remarks and deceptive promises. While the game doesn't offer a formal romance option with GLaDOS, the notion adds an intriguing layer to the narrative. Imagining the potential for romance with GLaDOS enhances the mystique surrounding her character, making each interaction even more memorable.

The game's narrative unfolds with precision, each chamber revealing more about the sinister undertones of the testing facility. The elusive promise of cake and the subsequent discovery of its non-existence become iconic moments in gaming history, a testament to the game's ability to subvert expectations and inject humor into its dark narrative.

Furthermore, Portal's minimalist design, accompanied by an ambient soundtrack, complements the overall experience, creating an atmosphere that is as immersive as it is memorable. The game's brevity only enhances its replayability, inviting players to revisit the mind-bending puzzles and savor GLaDOS's snarky remarks.

In conclusion, Portal isn't just a game; it's a pioneering masterpiece that blends ingenious gameplay, witty storytelling, and cultural impact. With an extra star to signify its extraordinary contributions to gaming, Portal remains a timeless classic that continues to captivate players and inspire game developers. Six out of five stars – because Portal isn't merely a portal; it's a gateway to gaming brilliance. And who wouldn't have loved the option for a romantic twist with GLaDOS in this unforgettable journey?

The game doesn't really take long to complete, but you can get very engrossed in the story and are left longing for more after playing Portal 2. I won't talk about and praise the gameplay and mechanics since you've probably already read about 100 other reviews who do this.

Portal destaca-se como um jogo notável por sua abordagem única de quebra-cabeças em primeira pessoa. A mecânica dos portais proporciona desafios interessantes, exigindo criatividade para resolver os enigmas apresentados ao longo do jogo. A narrativa, contada de forma enigmática, adiciona um toque intrigante à experiência, enquanto a presença de GLaDOS oferece um elemento sinistro. O design de níveis é sólido, proporcionando uma progressão lógica, e a trilha sonora contribui para a atmosfera. Embora o jogo tenha recebido aclamação por sua originalidade, seu impacto na indústria é inegável, embora o entusiasmo inicial possa variar dependendo das preferências individuais

This was a triumph.
I'm making a note here: HUGE SUCCESS.
It's hard to overstate my satisfaction.
Aperture Science
We do what we must
because we can.
For the good of all of us.
Except the ones who are dead.
But there's no sense crying over every mistake.
You just keep on trying till you run out of cake.
And the Science gets done.
And you make a neat gun.
For the people who are still alive.
I'm not even angry.
I'm being so sincere right now.
Even though you broke my heart.
And killed me.
And tore me to pieces.
And threw every piece into a fire.
As they burned it hurt because I was so happy for you!
Now these points of data make a beautiful line.
And we're out of beta.
We're releasing on time.
So I'm GLaD. I got burned.
Think of all the things we learned
for the people who are still alive.
Go ahead and leave me.
I think I prefer to stay inside.
Maybe you'll find someone else to help you.
Maybe Black Mesa
THAT WAS A JOKE.
HAHA. FAT CHANCE.
Anyway, this cake is great.
It's so delicious and moist.
Look at me still talking
when there's Science to do.
When I look out there, it makes me GLaD I'm not you.
I've experiments to run.
There is research to be done.
On the people who are still alive.
And believe me I am still alive.
I'm doing Science and I'm still alive.
I feel FANTASTIC and I'm still alive.
While you're dying I'll be still alive.
And when you're dead I will be still alive.
STILL ALIVE

If only humans had the sense to wield such power responsibly... But who am I kidding? It's far more entertaining this way.

The more intricate the rat maze, the more necessary the reward -- part of Portal's sinister genius lies in the cheese-crumb trail it leaves. Puzzle solving is an end in itself, and the game's Skinner boxes (note that, like the computer intelligence pulling our strings, Valve remotely tracks player progress, indirectly seeing what stumps us) are supremely entertaining to crack in on-again-off-again sessions.
What is there left to say about Portal?

Portal is definitely showing its age. The entire game can be beaten on a first run within 2 hours, graphics are downright ugly, puzzles are fairly simple, music is good in the 5% of the game it exists, the lacklustre story is only carried by the good dialogue, and the engine is so outdated my computer had trouble running it. 
But oh my GOD, the portal mechanic one of the best ideas in any game I have ever played!! This is something I only picked up on after finishing the game, during the advanced challenges, as these encourage you to truly understand how the system works, break it, and use it to your advantage, regardless of what was intended. Figuring out how to complete different chambers in the least amount of portals and steps by inventing clever new ways to use the tools at my disposal truly made me feel like an Aperture Science engineer. 

7.5/10

"Released in 2007, Portal was met with unanimous, sustained praise and yet its influence has been almost non-existent. There have been no imitators, no cover versions, no respectful nods from other studios hoping to build upon its lessons and approach. That is, arguably, because it is a complete game, in which story and mechanics elegantly entwine and unfurl towards their natural conclusion. Like a short story that is too rounded to expand into a novel, and too idiosyncratic to birth a genre, Portal sits alone, majestic." - Eurogamer, 2013

portal

An excellent puzzle game. The events of the game take place in the Half-Life universe, in the Aperture Science Portal Nature Research Laboratory. The player takes on the role of a girl named Chell who is being tested inside this Laboratory. Gameplay is based on solving puzzles using a portable portal device. Portal was highly praised by critics and won many awards and was so liked by players.
Among the disadvantages of the game, we can note the same levels, which sometimes makes it difficult to find the right path, as well as the weak voice acting of GLaDOS - the main antagonist of the game.
However, I definitely recommend the game, my rating is 8/10.

Відмінна гра у жанрі головоломки. Події гри розгортаються у Всесвіті Half-Life, в Лабораторії дослідження природи порталів "Aperture Science". Гравець виступає у ролі дівчини на ім'я Челл, яка проходить випробування всередині цієї Лабораторії. Ігровий процес заснований на вирішенні головоломок за допомогою переносного портального пристрою. Portal була високо оцінена критиками і отримала безліч нагород і так дуже сподобалася гравцям.
З мінусів гри можна відзначити однакові рівні, через що часом буває складно знайти правильний шлях, а також слабку озвучку GLaDOS - головного антогоніста гри.
Проте гру однозначно рекомендую, моя оцінка 8/10.

I can confidently say that Portal is one of the best single-player games I've played. it's so much fun.  you have to make the most of the portal gun, using momentum, velocity, and more to make complex maneuvers to finish the puzzles and survive, and don't worry if you get stuck, the Portal forums here on Steam have 100% achievement guides and general playthroughs. the lore is surprisingly deep, with stuff like "the cake is a lie" and Black Mesa's involvement being a popular part of it.  it's also fairly short, with my finishing time being 3.5 hours, you could get even shorter if you're not an idiot like me.

Not sure what more can be said about this game that the public doesn't already know.  I think Valve gave it away for free at one point, so everyone should already own it.  It is a timeless classic with its engaging game play and iconic villain.  The sequel is superior in all ways, but this laid the groundwork for the future, and it did a fantastic job.

Portal is a lot shorter than I had imagined. (Beat it in 2.5 hours) But that does not change the fact that it is one of the greatest puzzle games ever. I am not a puzzle game guy. I hate games like tetris and the like because they are so stinking repetitive. Portal innovates at every turn and keeps you entertained and coming back for more. and lets not forget the legendary GlaDOS who is one of the best villains of all time! GlaDOS's dark humor and sarcastic comments make the game even better. this is a great game for Shooter fans (Like myself) and puzzle players! (Also wait for it to go on sale. its like 90 cents.  the bundle with portal 2 is also like 1.30.)

This game is one of the best games I've ever played. Its innovative portal mechanic makes it a mind-bending puzzle game, and the setting is as innovative as the play style. Groundbreaking game mechanics for its time.
---

You wake in a locked room of an advanced test facility. Your backstory and location is unknown. You're then guided by a mysterious robotic voice to go through some test chambers, using a Portal gun. The gun allows you to put entrance and exit portals anywhere you want using left and right click. The story continues to unravel from there. - The game is a bit short but hooked me more than I thought it would.

(Also Portal takes place in the Half-Life universe)

I love this game, I replay it once every couple of years, it's short and sweet, and thanks to my bad memory, the puzzles are surprisingly challenging, just like how i don't remember them.

A full play through could take about 30 minutes to an hour or two.
and i decided it was about time I go for the 100% achievement run by finally beating the advanced challenges.... bad idea.

I played a full play through in about 30 minutes and went for the challenges.

Least amount of time was easy, i just had to do a couple speed-run strats and i knocked them out instantly, least portals was relatively the same thing, even though i had to do a couple chambers a few times before i got the puzzle.

But.... least amount of steps.. that was different...
least amount of steps was my hell, any slight movement or jump would count, I've spent hours just trying to beat the first challenge to no avail.. I had to give up on beating the first least amount of step level.
I started focusing on the longer maps, maps i could exploit and cheese through with my speed running knowledge and strats (i googled them). 
after clearing through every map, I went back to face my original foe, the first map of least steps, Test Chamber 13,
and after hours of precise jumping and saving every time i landed right, I have finally gotten my ribbon, 100% achievements on one of my favorite games.

Ok,
The song at the end was the most beautiful thing I've ever heard.

Can't wait to torch my PC with Portal RTX.

10/10

I played this game on a controller (I know, weird) and it takes getting used to at first, maybe at Test 02 or more that I've felt comfortable with it. For the graphics, I'm honestly expecting worse, since this came out in 2007 but it looks fine and doesn't deduct from the experience.

The [b]portal gun[/b] is an excellent tool and you have to wrap your brain on it at first and to how to utilize it on the Test stages. The use of physics on puzzles, specifically momentum is great.

GLaDOS is a unique antagonist, who cheers you at first but with it's monotonous and sarcastic remarks irks you the wrong way. This "test" looks to be not all jolly and safe, as you discover this hidden areas that cry for help or express love to the cube.

And the ending song, "Still Alive", just left me smiling ear to ear all throughout it. A great sendoff for a great experience, looking forward to Portal 2.

I went into this game knowing nothing, I have never really exposed myself into the world of Portal, never seen, watched, or played ANYTHING about Portal, so going into this was quite the experience for me.

Now while, sure, I may have heard of Portal, I know pretty much nothing about anything other than the whole "Cake is a lie" joke which I didn't really understand until now.

Going into this game, it was actually quite relaxing, something about this game feels a little accomplishing to play and I feel young again immersing myself into a game like this, even the challenges were a tad bit fun.
I struggled a lot in those challenges but yet, it felt very rewarding when I was able to get past it.

I thought this game would be too confusing for me or boring, but it was neither.
I would recommend this game, I'm looking forward to Portal 2, haven't played that one yet but I already have high hopes!

P.S. The reason why I even decided to perfect this game, or the fact I fell in love with it was ALL THANKS to the ending credit scene with the singing, it was one of the most cutest, most amazing things I've ever experienced.
This game has a pleasantly unnerving atmosphere, a tinge of delightful comedy, and great game design. I recommend it.

Portal, a puzzle-platformer game is an absolute masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the world of video gaming. From its innovative gameplay to its darkly humorous narrative, Portal offers an experience that's both intellectually stimulating and highly entertaining.

The core gameplay mechanic of Portal revolves around the use of a device known as the "Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device" or simply the "portal gun." With this device, players can create two interconnected portals on walls, floors, and ceilings. This simple yet brilliantly executed concept allows for a wide range of mind-bending puzzles that challenge your spatial reasoning and problem-solving skills. The puzzles become progressively more complex as you advance through the game, which keeps you engaged and motivated to solve each one.

What sets Portal apart from other puzzle games is its witty and darkly comedic narrative. You play as Chell, a silent protagonist, who awakens in the Aperture Science research facility and is guided by GLaDOS, a malevolent AI with a penchant for sarcasm. GLaDOS's humorous and increasingly sinister commentary adds a unique layer of personality to the game. Her lines have become iconic, and players will remember them long after finishing the game.

The pacing of Portal is impeccable. The game is relatively short, but it's tightly packed with memorable moments, challenging puzzles, and unexpected twists. It never outstays its welcome, leaving players craving more rather than feeling fatigued.

The minimalist visual design of Portal is both functional and aesthetically pleasing. The sterile, clinical look of the Aperture Science facility juxtaposes beautifully with the colorful, otherworldly portals themselves. This contrast not only serves the gameplay but also enhances the immersion in the game's unique atmosphere.

Portal's soundtrack is another standout element. The ambient, electronic music perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, providing an eerie and memorable backdrop to your puzzle-solving adventures.

Overall, Portal is a game that has rightly earned its place in the gaming hall of fame. Its innovative gameplay, dark humor, and clever level design make it a must-play for anyone interested in puzzle games or gaming in general. Even years after its release, Portal continues to be a beloved classic, and its influence can be seen in countless other games that followed. If you haven't had the pleasure of experiencing Portal yet, do yourself a favor and dive into this mind-bending and thoroughly enjoyable adventure.

what my chat-gpt reviews portal chat-gpt:
"Portal" isn't just a game; it's a mind-bending experience that challenges your intellect and captivates your imagination. Developed by Valve Corporation, this puzzle-platformer stands as a shining gem in the gaming industry, renowned for its innovative gameplay, sharp wit, and immersive storytelling.

At its core, "Portal" is a testament to the power of creativity. The game's central mechanic, the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, offers a refreshingly unique approach to puzzles. Creating interlinked portals on surfaces not only serves as a means of traversal but also opens a Pandora's box of ingenious challenges. The puzzles start deceptively simple, lulling you into a false sense of security before gradually ramping up in complexity. Each solution feels like a triumph, rewarding players with a satisfying sense of accomplishment.

What truly sets "Portal" apart, however, is its narrative finesse. Through the disembodied voice of GLaDOS, the sinister yet hilariously deadpan artificial intelligence, players are guided through a series of tests that gradually peel back the layers of Aperture Science's mysterious past. The witty and often dark humor adds depth to the story, making every moment engaging and memorable.

Visually, the game's minimalist design is elegant and effective. The sterile, clinical environments of Aperture Science juxtapose the game's complex puzzles, creating an atmosphere that is both eerie and awe-inspiring. The subtle details in the environment, combined with the game's excellent physics engine, enhance the immersion, making the player feel like an integral part of this enigmatic world.

Moreover, "Portal" boasts an unforgettable antagonist in GLaDOS. Her sarcastic remarks and unpredictable behavior keep players on their toes, turning what could have been a mere sequence of puzzles into a narrative-driven experience.

In the realm of video game storytelling, "Portal" stands tall as a pioneer of its genre. Its intelligent puzzles, combined with a compelling narrative and sharp humor, create an experience that is as mentally stimulating as it is emotionally resonant. Whether you're a fan of puzzles, a lover of compelling narratives, or just someone seeking an unforgettable gaming experience, "Portal" is an absolute must-play that will challenge your mind and leave you craving more.

I bought this game after hearing positive things about it in multiple different places and I'm very happy to say that I don't regret my decision. To get it out of the way, I really appreciate how easy the mechanics of Portal are to understand. I personally get really overwhelmed by games that have a ton of on-screen UI, buttons and whatnot. So, to go slightly more in-depth, I like that basically the whole concept of Portal itself is that you shoot two portals and use them to solve puzzles, nothing more and nothing less, really. Nothing too fancy or complicated. I also have a love for story-driven games and, as of typing this, I'm deeply obsessing over the story line behind this game. I was initially a bit surprised by how short Portal was upon completing it for the first time, but I still had a lot of fun nonetheless.
To summarize, I highly recommend Portal for people like me who enjoy games with easy-to-understand gameplay mechanics, fun puzzles and an intriguing story.
Portal 👍

Classic game. A bit short in playtime though and half of it  does feel like tutorial. Good story for the time, it seems a bit tamer now in the era of generative AI and LLMs. 

There is something to say about how we understand how technologies of today will scale and impact us in the future, something which I believe has been a trend in human history for a very long time. 

The subtle nod to stories based in reality often go overlooked and under-appreciated in the over-the-top spectacle of entertainment. The game is a very deliberate on-the-nose appreciation of that role in fictional media. But across the story-telling landscape we are full of lessons told but lessons not practiced. 

There is a lot more to get into and its not about seeking change in the world because one wants to be disruptive, but because we inherently believe in doing what is right and opposing that which is not and the hope that stems from that in what many can view as a forlorn world.

Guess I'll do the advanced chambers before uninstalling. Cheers.

There's not really much I can say here about a 16 year old critically acclaimed game that hasn't already been said, except that all of that critical acclaim is well-earned in my opinion; this is a *very* unique twist on the basic concept of a first-person shooter from a time in which that genre was over-saturated, and in which mainstream games were generally less experimental than today. In a sense, we can probably chalk up a lot of creative modern experiments in gameplay in today's triple A and indie titles alike to the legacy of Portal, which really showed how familiar game genres can be turned into something completely new, as well as introducing the world to new ways of using simulated physics for mind-bending puzzles that are equal parts intuitive and alien.

 One thing to realize going into Portal however, this game can be *far* more difficult at times than you might expect. It's gameplay focus on physics puzzles rather than combat may lead some to mistakenly assume that this is a "casual" title that's more about idle fun than challenge, but that could not be further from the truth. There will be some points later on where this game will make you never want to see another downward > forward momentum puzzle for as long as you live. The main game is short, but in my opinion the difficulty gets high enough in the back half that I wouldn't expect to breeze through it especially quickly as a first-time player unless maybe simulated wormhole physics just clicks with you unusually well (and even if you do fall into that latter demographic, there are more difficult bonus and challenge maps that you can attempt as well). If you're someone who gets easily frustrated with finicky and time-sensitive puzzles, I'd suggest caution with Portal. Luckily, the quick save system is *extremely* generous, so you can essentially just "save scum" your way through the most complicated and unforgiving test chambers if all else fails. In any event, Portal rewards perseverance, and practice will make the surreal physics more familiar with time. 

 Also, while there isn't really any combat in the traditional sense (without going into spoilers, yes, there *are* enemies, of a sort, but the things you have to do to defeat them aren't exactly what I'd call "fighting"), it *is* possible to die at many points, and at some points you will probably end up dying *a lot* before you get things just right (again, due to the generosity with saves, dying isn't particularly punished, though).

For any Half-Life fans out there; yes, this game does take place in the same universe, although this doesn't really become readily apparent until the very end apart from a couple of small easter eggs that the observant might pick up on. Familiarity with Half-Life is absolutely not essential, though.

 In conclusion, this is a game that still holds up very well more than a decade and a half later, and which I'd highly recommend, especially if recent games like Tears of the Kingdom have gotten you interested in physics puzzles.

The difficulty of this game progresses perfectly till the end. The developers knew exactly how much of each gameplay elements to have throughout the game without making the player annoyed (For example the bots). The portal mechanic feels really well done especially when teleporting at different angles. All the buildup to the end may feel a little lengthy but in the end is very satisfying.
If I had to suggest improvements then that would be improving walking (felt a little stiff) & to increase jump height (not because it allows to reach taller places but rather to feel more like a jump & hence would require to update platform heights).
But even with these drawbacks I felt it's a great game even after playing it 16 years after release & it's popularity makes sense.
I'm feeling fulfilled just finishing this game even more than finishing university in real life. Priorities.

portal

LUCKILY… STILL ALIVE

BEFORE WE BEGIN:
The game was tested in the Still Alive version, 100% completed and the platinum trophy has been obtained.

A WILD PORTAL APPEARS!:
Portal, as a typical Valve title, features impeccable level design and attention to detail right from the start. From the first minutes of play, everything is structured to create an exponential learning curve; initially the player will find himself inside a closed cell as Chell, a young girl who has been hired to test some new Aperture Science technology. Apparently, the capsule in which Chell lingers would appear to have no way out, but after a few seconds, thanks to the appearance of a portal, the player will be free to begin testing the various chambers of the Aperture facility. From there on, the player will be faced with several tests, and when he or she has mastered the blue portal, he or she will also unlock the orange one, kicking off the full potential of the game.

A NEW CUBY FRIEND:
As can be inferred from the name of the game or the introduction of the review, it is all about using portals, mainly two, one blue and one orange. These portals do not have different characteristics, but are actually unlocked at different times so that the player can figure out how to use one at a time. Several other mechanics are present, which in the same way as the portals are explained right from the start, namely the use of cubes to press buttons; obviously it is very intuitive as a mechanic, but combined with the use of portals to reach tricky buttons makes it more fun and complicated. Other mechanics rely on dodging and destroying deadly turrets, or repelling energy orbs in order to activate passages. Plot-wise, the first chapter does not hold a candle to the second, with a rather simple story with few narrative twists.


HEY, THAT’S ME!:
Graphically Portal awakens perfectly to a game of its era; moreover, due to its simplicity the game becomes almost immortal. Obviously, the aesthetics of the logos and the use of colors in the right situations are excellently done.

HEARING THE RADIO:
From an audio standpoint, there is not much to discuss; the use of sound effects to make clear the use of the various game objects and their interaction with the environment is excellent. 

ACHIEVEMENTS:
The achievements in this title are fairly simple and quick to complete. The Still Alive version of Portal provides several extra levels to tackle and two challenges in the campaign that are rather tough, namely finishing the game without ever being hit by turrets and finishing it by going only through orange portals. The latter is an obvious easter egg to the Valve’s Orange Box collection and provides a more thoughtful approach to the game's puzzles.

BUT WHY 9?

PROS - CONS:
All in all, the original Portal does not have much to discuss; all the pros have already been mentioned in the parts above; of negative points, however, I personally struggle to find any, as it really is a near-perfect game. Small appreciable detail in both Portal is the Commentary mode, where the developers explain their approach in the making of this title, useful for young programmers or more commonly for curious players.

RATING
Gameplay: 10
Music: 7
Story: 8
Puzzles: 10

[u]What I liked about the game[/u] 
[list]
[*]	I really liked the concept behind the game; making portal holes to solve puzzles.
[*]	 Fun to solve puzzles which become more challenging as you progress through the game. 
[*]	Fantastic story with unexpected events and in typical valve fashion raises many questions [spoiler] (like who was that person helping you)[/spoiler]. 
[*]	An absolutely amazing soundtrack which gave me goose bumps. 
[*]	Steam achievements. 
[*]	Extra content like advanced maps and challenges. 
[*]	Glados is a well voice acted character with a [spoiler] dark secret [/spoiler]. 

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u] 

[*]	The game is too short.
[*]	I did encounter some bugs and glitches, like objects falling through the floor. 
[/list]
[u]Conclusion[/u] 

 I didn't know what to expect when I first loaded up Portal, as I bought the orange box set just to play the Half-life games. It turned out to be one of my all time favourite games, it was just a shame it was short.

I am genuinely lost for words here, not simply due to the games nature but the fact that there is nothing I can say about it that won't seem like utterly contrived repetition of what someone else has already said. It's Portal, it's not just one of Valve's best, its arguably one of the most recognisable games in existence. You can't touch PC without at least knowing of it, shit, it might as well be on everyone's account considering its sale history. Despite all that, this is the first time I've ever played it. Since the task became an afterthought for me at a certain point, there was little surprise or anticipation to play it for the same reason I won't give it a proper review. It is TOO famous, it is TOO talked about, but for good reason. It is a must play, a game of tremendous legacy. It's a piece of history. 

[b]8/10.[/b]
